Reviews.Title: Just fine.
Reviews.Author: EmTee
Reviews.Content: I've had this drive in a computer for storing video, not so much recording streams.  I purchased this elsewhere, before the flood in thailand for a ridiculous price that we'll never see again.  I've also backed up regular data on it.  I created this review simply to stop the misinformation stream here.  This drive is CAPABLE OF ignoring read or write errors but the way it stores data on the drive, and its ability to check errors is the same as any other desktop drive.  When used in a PC, the read/write modes that ignore errors are not used (and I believe cannot be used, may be wrong though).  Consumer electronics devices such as DVRs are the devices that might use this read/write mode.  You can find this information elsewhere, quoted directly from hard drive manufacturers in regards to these drives.  There is nothing dangerous about using them in for data, in raid etc. as compared to other desktop drives.

Reviews.Title: WD20EURS is the Drive to Get to Upgrade Your Tivo Hard Drive
Reviews.Author: Inspired Dribble
Reviews.Content: Six months ago I bought a Tivo Premiere XL with 150 HD hours of recording (has a WD10EURS 1TB Western Digital Drive in it).  Shortly later, after recording numerous high density videos I ran out of space.  Since it was more than 30 days since I had my Tivo, Tivo refused to allow me to swap out my player for an upgrade or put in another hard drive, other than buying another whole new Tivo!.I considered simply adding an external hard drive built specifically for Tivo, a simple fix (by the way, Tivo charges about twice what you can get them from Amazon, etc).  However, since I am familiar with computers and after reading how the external drives seem not hold up so well in the long run and how you might loose the programs stored on both the main drive and the external if it ever dysfunctions or you disconnect the external hard drive, I decided to just have one larger drive inside the Tivo with more recording capability.I searched on line and in the Tivo forums found that upgrading my Tivo Premiere XL would be easy and that I could increase my recording potential from 150 Hrs with the 1 TB drive in it to 300HD hours with a 2 TB WD20EURS drive (already maximized with reliability, power saving and compatible functions for Tivo and Video recording - 3 Yr Warranty).  All I needed to do was copy the contents of my current 1 TB Tivo which is already a WD10EURS to 2 TB using a Western Digital WD20EURS Hard Drive as the target drive.  By the way,  Tivo software at present WILL NOT support a 3TB drive, so do not buy one of those.To do that, I found a reference to a program called JMFS, rev 104 in Tivo forums after a Yahoo internet search.  I downloaded it, and and when I clicked on the download, I was given the option of burning the disk which I did creating a boot cd with the JMFS program on it.I then repeatedly hit F2 as my computer was starting to change the boot order to CD Rom before hard disk (change this back to hard drive when done with the copy procedure). I unplugged my Tivo, then using a Torx T10 and T15 screwdriver (purchased at Ace or online), I removed the four screws to the Tivo cover and then slid back the cover to my Tivo, and being careful not to touch anything else inside (possible shock), I removed the current Tivo hard drive which has four Torx screws holding the rail inside .  I then inserted the JMFS boot drive into my computers second CD drive and turned OFF my computer, opened the side of my computer and disconnected the power and sata belt to my computers main hard drive (leave the computers hard drive in the machine) and then connected the power and SATA plugs freed up inside my computer from disconnecting the hard drive(s) in the machine to both the old Tivo drive taken out of my Tivo and the new 2 TB drive I am copying to.  (hard drives now sitting on floor both connected next to computer).  I then started the machine allowing my computer to start and boot up from the JMFS boot disk in the CD Rom.  The program showed me both the older smaller Tivo Drive and the Newer Larger Drive and then gave me the option to copy from the smaller to the larger (make sure that you have this right), and after the copy finished (about 3-4 hours), I was given the option to expand my new drive to 2 TB for tivo, and then to supersize which only took about one second each.Done!  Nothing else needed to be done since the WD20EURS is already optimized to work with Tivo (no need to worry about parking or seek speeds or running the Wdidle program).  I simply put the new drive into my Tivo, and now it says 320 Hrs of HD recording available.Naturally, to make my computer usable again, I turned it off and  disconnected the Tivo Drives, and reconnected my hard drive power and sata belts, and started my computer hitting F2 again to access the setup and bios program and changed back the order of the boot to hard drive first.Note, that the WD20EURS needs to be aligned if instead of puting it into a Tivo or video recorder you leave it inside your computer running with Windows XT in place unless you align the hard drive first (a jumper setting), however, this is not a problem setting up a tivo drive as the JMFS boot disk that you made has its own operating system that you use when you boot and the fact that windows XT might be on your computer is totally irrelevant to the copy procedure.  So don't worry about windows XT being on your computer for this copy procedure and don't add a jumper or alter or align the WD20EURS when you get it!If I had known I was going to buy an upgrade drive, I probably would have purchased the $400 Tivo Premiere XL4 machine (cheaper on Amazon) with 300 HD hours already available and the ability to record four channels at a time instead of 2 channels and only 150 HD recording hours like the Tivo Premiere XL.  By the way, you can get a refurbished Premiere XL from Tivo with 150 HD hours for $150 at present.  And of course, it may be wise to save the old Tivo drive removed as a backup should your new drive ever fail or to put in the machine for a factory return if you need service later.The instructions to do this upgrade may be slightly different for an older version than a Tivo Premiere, however, they are readily available on the internet.  If you are not confident about doing this and are out of space, the external drive may be a much better option for you.Of course, a computer shop or hard drive cloner tool may be able to clone your Tivo Drive onto the larger drive.  However, you may still need to run the JMFS boot disk to expand the new drive to the full 300Hrs recording time and supersize (for another 20 hours) the disk and if you have less than a Premiere machine, you may need to use a different program to supersize (instructions on line).The new drive does not invalidate the ownership of your Tivo, which is recognized from a microchip in the machine.  Also, this process works fine with a machine with Windows XP as mentioned since you are using the Unix Operating system on the JMFS boot disk.  My drive although bulk OEM, was easily recognized and used for the copying of my older drive to the new.  Other drives may work for this procedure, but the WD20EURS is an AV drive optimized to conserve its resources when not being used and to be more reliable in the long run.As a side note, Comcast in our area only broadcasts at 720dpi even in high definition.  When I set my Tivo to record higher than that, the picture looked terrible, some sort of bad upsampling apparently.  So, if you don't like your picture, try setting your tivo for recording at 720 dpi.

Reviews.Title: Update: Actually Recertified, Not New
Reviews.Author: PaleGreen1
Reviews.Content: I ordered one of these 2 TB drives from Storite, through Amazon, on Jan 16, 2014.  The label on the drive says it's a WD20EURS WD AV-GP, but it also says Recertified.  When I checked the warranty on wdc.com, it said the model number is WDBAAU0020HBK-NESN, 2 TB WD Elements Desktop, and that the warranty expires on 4/11/2014!Also, when I plugged the drive into my computer, it was already formatted and the volume label is ELEMENTS.So it looks like I received a recertified Elements hard drive.  So I now I wonder if it has the AV-GP firmware or not.I've opened a case with WD support.  I'll let you know what they say.UPDATE:I heard back from WD Support.  This drive is a recertified drive, as the label says.  WD will extend the warranty to 3 years from the ship date, after I send proof of purchase and a photo of the drive.Since the drive is being sold as New on Amazon, I don't think it's right for Storite to ship recertified drives instead.  I don't really have a problem with recertified products in most cases, but they should definitely be listed as such, so you know what you're buying.

Reviews.Title: Great and perfect hard drive for a video surveillance system
Reviews.Author: Sarge
Reviews.Content: Great and perfect hard drive for a video surveillance system.I recently bought and set up a Zmodo video surveillance  system that came without a hard drive. After careful investigation and shopping, I found that this drive, which was recommended by the makers of the system I had, was a perfect fit. I have been using it now, for over 7 months without a problem. It runs and records constantly, non-stop and when the drive gets full, it starts recording over the oldest recordings. The massive 2-TB size, lets you save a great deal of video without worry. I'd buy this drive again, if I had to install another system.

Reviews.Title: WD20EURS - ONLY USE DVR's or Security Camera's Etc.
Reviews.Author: Kelly Owens
Reviews.Content: this drive is amazing! ive got 1 in my tivo Premiem HD and wow is it fast and good! also have 2 in the Security Camera dvr setup again its not missed a beat!BUT i must warn you now DO NOT USE THIS IN A COMPUTER YOU WILL STORE DATA ON IE DOCUMENTS ETC!!!!!THE REASON FOR THIS IS BELOWThe A/V drives ignore errors, the normal drives will do an error recovery to attempt to get back any data from the platter.When recording video (security cameras etc) you want an A/V drive that will just record whatever you throw at it, and keep going even if it misses a byte or two. An error in a couple of bytes just causes a minor blip in the video stream, but the rest won't stop. On a normal drive it could go into an error recovery mode and stop recording for 10-30 seconds - and this is much worse for security.However if you store documents, a single byte error could corrupt megabytes or even gigabytes of important data.Which you choose depends on your purpose.. but for DVR's, CCTV's Etc ie if its only going to have video on it then this is the kiddie you need!

Reviews.Title: Compatible with TivoHD

Reviews.Content: I used the WD20EURS to upgrade a TivoHDXL.  I did not encounter any issues with this drive during the upgrade process.  The drive runs silently.  The Tivo reports 318 hours of HD recording capacity after the upgrade.I used wdidle3.exe on the drive expecting that I would have to disable the disk idle timer feature of the drive to avoid Tivo hanging on soft reboot.  However, I was happy to find that the disk idle timer was already disabled by default on the new drive.  More info on the disk idle timer behavior can be found by searching the Tivo upgrade forums.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for a home server
Reviews.Author: Gyz "Ig"
Reviews.Content: I like these because they run cool and quiet, and don't require a lot of power. My home server has 5 of these, four in a RAID 5 array, and one spare. It also has 8GB of RAM, NVidia GT640 video, and an FX6300 CPU, all powered by a 500W supply. Sustained write speed is close to the 130MB/s rating as a stand alone drive.WD does not recommend using these in an array for performance reasons; they are SATA II (3Gb/s), and they spin at a lower RPM (probably 5200). Some reviewers are claiming that these drives are using some bizarre error correction scheme, different from a desktop hard drive, and are not to be used in desktop PCs. I believe this is totally bogus. I've read the specs and there is no mention of anything like that. These drives are designed for A/V applications like DVRs which run 24/7 and have predictable data rates. They are not a performance drive, so don't use it as your boot drive. But for storing data, these drives are great.

Reviews.Content: I bought this HDD, along with a Vantec Nexstar CX case, to use with my Verizon FiOS DVR.  Works great.  Since the Vantec case is fanless, you would be able to hear the HDD spin ... if it made any sound at all.  Well, it's completely silent because this hard drive is very very quiet.The FiOS DVR is noisier than this, so it adds nothing to the noise level.I can't comment as to its longevity and/or durability since I just put it into service.  But if it's anything like my other WD drives, it'll be working for a long long time.

Reviews.Title: DirecTV TiVo THR22 Replacement Works Flawlessly
Reviews.Author: stlouisbrad "stlouisbrad"
Reviews.Content: This is the one "sure thing" drive to get if you want to replace the factory capacity of your DirecTV TiVo THR22.I tried to use this as an external drive tethered to my THR22 by eSATA, but nothing worked (not Western Digital's fault).  So I man'd up and got a Torx screwdriver set at Home Depot.  After watching a video on YouTube I opened the THR22 and replaced the stock 500GB unit in 15 minutes.Note, the replacement drive (500GB) has a foam spacer on top.  This 2TB drive is taller and probably doesn't need the foam (I left it in).  You will lose all video (EVERYTHING) on your factory stock 500GB drive in the THR22.  Interestingly, the THR22 has the startup (boot) software stored in the firmware.  Last time I did this (years ago) you had to clone the factory drive.  It's easy now!I have so much space with this new drive I just get season passes on shows I might want to watch in a few years.  I turned it loose on the pre-finale Breaking Bad marathon on AMC and got the entire series.  There are still hundreds of hours left thanks to the massive capacity of this drive.

Reviews.Title: Best and largest DVR HD drive currently supported
Reviews.Author: B. Althaus
Reviews.Content: Used to upgrade my TiVo Premiere from a small 320GB drive (~40hrs) to 318 hours.If you're planning on upgrading your DVR then this is the best and largest HD as 2GB is currently the largest drive most DVR's (or even PC's) can handle w/o a new host bus controller (HBA).  And even then the OS might not handle it (Windows and Linux).  I know this as I originally ordered the 2.5GB drive only to find out that Windows only recognized (2.18GB's).  When I went to WD's website FAQ it's only there where it's explain why they ship an HBA card with the full box version.  And even with the HBA most OS's won't work with HD's > 2GB.  Save yourself a lot of time and trouble and just purchase this drive.I've had this drive for 2 weeks now and I've yet to even hear it!  That's how quite it is.  I've also not have one on screen glitch or pause on my TiVo with this drive.  Very happy.-Bryan

Reviews.Title: Perfect for expanding Verizon FIOS DVR storage via eSATA
Reviews.Author: Richard Park "Rick in LA"
Reviews.Content: The current Verizon FIOS DVRs come with 500GB internal storage and the capability to expand via an eSATA connected drive.  Verizon officially recommends 2 Western Digital external drives with eSATA connectivity; other drives are not certified to work.  The drive reviewed is of the same design as what is in the WD external drives.  It's designed specifically for DVR/surveillance equipment meaning it does not have highly complex data correction features which is a good thing for DVR/surveillance since the process of data correction can result in loss of synch with the realtime data that is being collected.  An occasional drop in data in these applications will not hurt the performance.  However, these drives are not suitable for other PC/server applications where data integrity is paramount.I had a Seagate drive which caused all sorts of problems and lock-ups with the FIOS DVR.  It was mounted in one of those external SATA stands where the drive drops in to a slot.  Simple and inexpensive and the exposed drive gets more than enough cooling since most of it is exposed to air.  Replaced it with this drive and the lock-up problems have gone away.Note:  some external cases like the Rosewill Rx-358 V2 will spin down the drive and in the case of the FIOS box, it no longer is able to start the drive back up.  So even though it thinks it's connected to the drive, you need to go into the FIOS DVR settings and eject it, then power cycle the external drive which will recover it - until the next time the Rosewill box powers down the drive.  So I don't recommend mounting the drive in this particular Rosewill case for FIOS use.Otherwise, this drive is excellent and provides more storage than I can envision needing for programs.

Reviews.Title: Used To Upgrade Tivo Series 3 DVR
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: Upgraded my Tivo Series 3 (648) DVR using this drive. I previously upgraded this same Tivo from the original Western Digital 250GB drive to a Hitachi Deskstar 1TB drive back in 2009.  When originally purchased this Tivo was capable of storing 32 HD hours, and 300 SD hours. After the first upgrade these figures went up to 144 hours HD, and approxiamtely 1300 hours SD.Fast forward to present, now with only 1% space left, time to delete some of that content or look for other options. After quite a bit of research, 'looked' like I could upgrade to a 2 TB drive.  I say 'looked,' due to lots of conflicting information regarding use of 2 TB drive with this particular Tivo DVR. Not to mention lots of suggestions as to which drive should be used, which is how I found this drive.  I can report a 2 TB drive can most definitely be used with this particular Tivo DVR. One caveat here, check your Tivo software version, have found many a site stating Tivo software version 11.XX or above is needed.  My Tivo has version 11, but perhaps versions under that would work? But without trying have no way of knowing for sure.For software I used WinMFS (note: not MFSLive), available free online. This software runs under a Windows environment. However you'll need a PC with Win XP service pack 2 or higher. WinMe or Win 95 will not work. You will also need a PC which has a SATA controller with at least two available (unused) ports. One port to hook up the current Tivo disk drive, the second to hook up the new drive you are going to copy to. If you only have access to a laptop, you can use a USB to SATA adapter. Though this likely will take longer to copy than the aforemention method. If your laptop has USB III ports, might not be too much difference.The WinMFS software will copy (Mfscopy) the current Tivo drive to the new drive, this will take several hours to complete. This process will also copy any previously recorded material. WinMFS will also resize (Mfsadd) the new drive to take advantage of the extra space. For example in my case I copied almost 1 TB of data to the new disk drive. I then used Mfsadd, to 'expand' this 1 TB image on the new drive, to the drives full 2 TB size.  You can also gain some additional space by setting MfsSuperSize to 'on.'  Various online info suggests keeping MfsSuperSize set to 'off' (default setting). Other sites suggest setting it to 'on.'  In my case I decided to set MfsSuperSize to 'on.'  This gained me an additional 25 hours of HD recording time.Something else I have read,  when Mfscopy is done, it will ask if you wish to resize? A number of sites suggest answering 'no' to that question. Then do it as a separate step using Mfsadd. That is exit out of WinMFS, start it back up, select your new drive, then do the Mfsadd.  I'm not sure if doing it in a separate step is necessary. But exiting out of the program, then back in only took a few seconds. So did it just that way. Right after running Mfsadd, I set MfsSuperSize to 'on.'Another thing to mention about WinMFS, is the command called Mfsinfo. I would suggest using this command before, during, and after you upgrade. Once you select your source drive (part of WinMFS process), you can run Mfsinfo. This will bring up a second window, there you will find stats on your current selected drive. This information can be saved to a text file. Then afterwards you can compare what each step has done for you.  For example as mentioned above run Mfsinfo before upgrading. Then once you have finished with Mfscopy, you can select your new drive, then run Mfsinfo. Once again save yourself a text file. Then again after doing the Mfsadd, and again after the MfsSuperSize. Make sure you change the text file name each time you save, otherwise you will overwrite the previous text file you saved.  The above is not necessary, simply meant as a way of keeping track of what is being accomplished.Also, prior to running Mfscopy, please be very careful when you are selecting a source drive and destination drive. If you make the mistake of making your current Tivo drive the destination drive, and your new blank upgrade drive as the source drive, you will wipe out your original Tivo drive. I've read the WinMFS software will actually prompt you with an error preventing you from doing so. But I would not want to bet my Tivo this is so. As such exercise a good deal of caution here.  Also some caution needs to be exercised when you first boot up Windows (after installing your original Tivo drive and your upgrade drive into your PC). After booting up, some versions of Windows may ask you if you wish to format what it thinks are new drives.  Do not answer yes or no, simply exit out of any such pop up.After completing the above, my Tivo went from 1%  space available to 51% available. Under Tivo's system information, it now shows 318 HD hours and 2777 SD hours (btw, these figures will show up in the Mfsinfo command).Now as far as the Western Digital drive; so far working great! Video quality same as before, that is to say excellent.  Also, very very quiet. The previous Hitachi drive, although would not call it loud, with the cabinet door open during quieter scenes, you could most definitely hear it softly clicking away in the background (at times even with the cabinet door closed). Again, would not describe this as loud, simply noticeable at times. This new Western Digital Drive, even with the TV muted and the cabinet door wide open, I have yet to hear it make a sound.A most definite 5 star drive!

Reviews.Title: Very good price

Reviews.Title: Great for added DVR storage with Verizon FiOS

Reviews.Title: Excellent Product

The harddrives on Amazon where cheaper than ordering on western digitals website so I crossed my fingers and ordered the drive. The drive arrived and I plugged it in and the drive rebuilt so I never lost any of my data.

Reviews.Content: I bought this to be my storage drive for my movies/TV/Music. I use my home PC as a media center or sorts, running Windows 8 on an 80G SSD and then a 250G for games, and this 2TB for Movies/TV/Music.The drive, so far, has performed wonderfully. Reviews.Title: Quiet

Reviews.Title: Great DVR Drive!

Reviews.Content: Perfect for TiVo upgrades. Quiet, reliable, no DOA's. I don't know of a better a/v drive. Great price at $104.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for DVR's

Reviews.Content: Got it for my dad as a Christmas present. He had that pitiful hard drive with Verizon FIOS that was always above 70% full. This is designed specifically for DVR's that can use an external drive for additional space, instead of using another drive and having to run all these circuit level commands and needing an active cooling case blah blah blah, I used a standard aluminum, passive case and external SATA cable in an enclosed cabinet and it barely gets warm.I will be getting one for myself when I get my computer connected to MY cable provider to drop one of my expensive boxes!

Reviews.Content: Ran the WD diagnostics program before going through the upgrade process...no errors.  It's been working great for the last couple of weeks.  Upgrade was easy and only took a few hours.  Went from 45 recordable HD hours to 317.I was so impressed with the price, ease of process, and benefits, that I ordered another for my second TiVo.As others have stated, use this hard drive only for DVR, surveillance recorders, etc.  There is a reason they are designed for such devices.

Reviews.Title: Perfect upgrade for a Tivo

Reviews.Content: Bumped my Tivo Premiere from 320 Gb to 2 Tb with this drive. I can't recommend this enough. I didn't realize how much we were missing when the Tivo was starved for space. Now we always have amazingly good recommendations automatically recorded. Much quieter than the original disk. Very happy with it.

Reviews.Title: Western Digital Failure

Reviews.Content: I had bought it to replace one of their USB drives that failed after two years only to have this unit fail too. This never worked and to make matters worse I had to pay to return it.  Always buy DIRECTLY through Amazon, they allow returns at no cost to the customer for those occasional problems.

Reviews.Title: Best HD for DTV DVR external
Reviews.Author: john brightup
Reviews.Content: Best HD for external Sat DVR. Recommeded for  esata drive enclosures. This drive plus esata cable and esata external drive enclosure.

Reviews.Title: Last Long, Great Customer Service
Reviews.Author: TanquerayG
Reviews.Content: I just replaced two of these drives, same model and size exactly, in my security camera DVR, a DVR known to shorten lives of drives.  I found one drive failing after 2.5 years of it's 3 year warranty.  I tested with Western Digital online software, verified the drive had 2 bad sectors, called Western Digital, gave them the serial number, they verified it was still under warranty, charged me only shipping one way (approx $6) and emailed me a pre-paid shipping label, and I sent it in for replacement.  Soooo easy.  It will very likely be a reconditioned drive warranted up to the end of the original 3 year warranty but that is reasonable, and you can bet it can carry the load for another 3 years.The other drive I replaced had no bad sectors.  It was 2.5 years into it's warranty.The replacement drives are these that I ordered here.  Same model exactly.  They are running a little cooler (perhaps engineering improvement).  Not failing now.  Using for only a month now.

Reviews.Title: Tivo HD upgrades
Reviews.Author: Frank and Lisa
Reviews.Content: I installed these in two of my Tivo HD's after I installed a premier with 4 tuners.  I called tivo to cancell service on the other two hd and they offered$99 lifetime service if I kept them.  I said sure and ordered these two drives.  l Now I have 318 hours of HD on each tivo HD and plan on keeping them for another 5 years.  These are great drives for 24/7 operation in tivos.

Reviews.Title: so far so good, adds lots of recording time to my DVR
Reviews.Author: PhilB
Reviews.Content: I bought this drive to connect it to my Motorola QIP 7232 2 DVR box from Verizon. It has been working well for a week now, its plugged into a Vantec NexStar3 eSata USB3.0 external enclosure and so far no issues at all.I have not done any speed tests or anything on this drive, I just connected it directly to the DVR and started recording.Edit: I've had this setup for several months now, everything still works perfectly. I highly recommend this to anyone that's considering getting more disk space for their DVR.

Reviews.Title: Override Hard Drive for my HR 24 Directv DVR
Reviews.Author: E. Baurys "Gbars"
Reviews.Content: I purchased this drive along with a "Thermaltake Max 5 Active Cooling Hard Drive Enclosure" to replace the 500GB hard drive in my DVR. The installation was amazingly simple; just had to pull the plug on the HR24 DVR, assemble the Thermaltake Cooler with the new hard drive, plug it in and attach the SATA cable from hard drive to the back of the DVR, allow the new drive to come up for about 5-10 minutes and then re-plug in the DVR. The DVR software then formats the new drive and after a few minutes your ready to go. The content on the DVR's hard drive is no longer available, but its still there should you ever want to revert back to the original DVR's configuration. Right now I've got about 20 to 30 hours of HD programming on the new drive and my unused available space sits at 96%. Again, simple installations like this seldom work for me the first time out, but this time I was pleasently surprised it went through without a hitch.

Reviews.Title: So far so good (until it died)
Reviews.Author: E. A. Bustos "Techie"
Reviews.Content: I bought this to go with a Zmodo DVR that I purchased that does not include the hard drive.  I wrote a review about the security system as well, and will re-iterate that if a machine is billed as a DVR then it is implied that the "R" is part of it.  Anyway, at least this way I can choose how much recording space I want it to have.  It was easy to install (I build my own computers so it's a no brainer for me, but it's very easy to see where the holes in the bottom of the hard drive line up with the DVR and to connect the cables) and once I turned on the DVR it was all set to go.  The DVR formatted the drive, and within about fifteen minutes it was recording.  So far all I can say is it's great, it's a WD green drive, and I don't expect any problems.  If I run into anything I will be sure to update my review.  I use three 1TB WD caviar drives in my own computer and they have not let me down even after a number of reformats, so I don't expect any problems here.UPDATE: I purchased this in March of 2013 and during the summer it started giving me problems.  The DVR started beeping and the drive light would stay on, indicating hard drive failure.  I opened the DVR, disconnected the drive and reconnected it, and everything seemed okay for a few months.  Now in January 2014, it really died.  No amount of disconnecting and reconnecting would resurrect the drive; it just is no longer recognized.  I also noticed the drive is now incredibly hot, even though the DVR is well ventilated as it sits on a large table with nothing around it.  I've initiated an RMA with Western Digital as it is still in-warranty (if you buy this, make note of the serial number and register it with Western Digital).  They have an option where you can give your credit card number and receive a replacement before sending the drive in, but I didn't want to do that as I wasn't really sure if they would charge my card or not.  So I was easily able to create an RMA and I just have to mail them the drive (I'm not happy about having to pay to ship them their defective item, but what can I do).  I will update my review after I see how long the process is with Western Digital.  For now I've knocked down the number of stars to three (from five) due to the rapid hard drive failure.

Reviews.Content: We are using this for a video surveillance system that has 14 cameras and recording to this drive. It has worked well so far, so I highly recommend an AV rated drive for surveillance application. We had problems with a previous drive that was not AV rated.

Reviews.Title: WD - Always the dependable standard

Reviews.Content: Bought to upgrade one of my TiVo Premiere DVRs. Working great so far, and would expect nothing less than a very long time of continueous, depedable service just as we've all come to trust in when it's a WD product.

Reviews.Title: Great for Upgrading / Repairing your Tivo

Reviews.Content: I have been buying the WD AV type drives for ~10 years now to upgrade and repair my Tivos. Never have had a problem out of any of them.

Reviews.Title: Excellent value as replacement drive for TiVo Premier
Reviews.Author: Pete "Amazon junkie"
Reviews.Content: Bought this after I started getting video drop-out on my TiVo Premier after about four years.  After researching other user recommendations on TiVo and Weaknees forums, I was able to copy my old shows onto this new drive and get 6X more storage space.  So far, it has worked without a hitch - quiet, no video problems.  Note that if you want to use this drive in your TiVo, it has to be specially formatted before you install it - see the forums.  However, with average technical ability (like me), it can be done.  Highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: 180 hrs of HD Tivo recording
Reviews.Author: Daddio Dave
Reviews.Content: I upgraded the hard drive in my Tivo HD with this drive. Easy to do using the instructions available on the internet (search the Engadget site for Tivo drive upgrade). I now have over 180 hours of HD recording available on my Tivo. Quite a jump from the previous 22 hours or so. So far no problems with the drive after 1 month. Now we can record whatever we want in HD and not have to worry about running out of space.

Reviews.Title: Good drive, quiet operation.
Reviews.Author: Humberto
Reviews.Content: I bought a couple of these to use in a pair of cctv DVR's. They are running 24/7. So far so good.  Lets see how they hold up.

Reviews.Author: Engineer
Reviews.Content: Have had this drive for about two months installed in a Sans Digital external enclosure with no problems. It's been my experience that defects in these larger drives can be detected to a high degree during the first 48 to 72 hours of service, if extensive surface testing is performed.

I read in the blogs for Directv that the disk was in the next size up DVR so we took a chance and so far so good.  Been running the system 3 months now with no problems.

Reviews.Title: Humming along
Reviews.Author: xoraclez
Reviews.Content: Bought a couple of these to use as external drives on Directv DVR's.  Mounted in a couple Rosewill esata enclosures they fit the bill perfectly.The ones shipped to me had the power saving mode disabled, so no need to run wdidle on these drives to prevent excessive head parking/load cycles.  As far as error correction claims, some people claim these drives do not hiccup on read/write errors, because of their intended use as DVR drives.  I'm not sure how accurate this is.  Especially considering most DVR's store their OS on the drive.  None the less, I have not observed any problems to date.The run quiet, and fairly cool, which is exactly why I bought these instead of the "Blue" drives.  Supposedly these drives use even less power than the "Green" drives, and don't require fiddling with wdidle to adjust the smart power setting.

Reviews.Title: Works great in Windows 7 - Horribly in Windows XP
Reviews.Author: Terry
Reviews.Content: I originally bought this for my XP machine, but it performed so poorly (around 1.3 MB / second) (even after installing the WD Advanced Format tool) I ended up swapping it out with an older drive from my Windows 7 machine.  I performs very well in Windows 7 (I was getting around 90 MB / second).  It ended up not being what I really wanted to do, because I wanted the 2TB in my XP machine, but I ended up swapping it out for the older 1TB.I would recommend that if you want a drive for Windows XP, do not get an Advanced Format drive.

Reviews.Title: CAUTION for Windows XP users
Reviews.Author: Victor Saraiva
Reviews.Content: Western Digital is shifting its large drives (2TB+) into a new alignment format which requires the user to use its proprietary acronis alignment/ formatting software if you are NOT using Windows 7 as a platform on your PC.  In order to get the software, you are MANDATED to register your hard drive's serial number with WD.  But even after doing so, I wasn't allowed to download the software.  Google this issue, and one can see that many other end users are having the same problem.  WD TECH support was slow to respond to my query, and even then, never provided me with a direct link for the download.  I was unable to use MSDOS commands to FDISK, never mind format the damn thing.I was finally able to realign the disk with a LINUX program that reset it to 512 Kb rather than the 4096 Kb per sector that WD is NOW using.WD is intentionally attempting to deny access to its alignment/format software that would render its product serviceable to its end user.  WHY? Maybe I got a crappy know-nothing Techie at WD, or MAYBE I came face to face with a new mandate from Homeland Security ( maybe they got NO CYBER LISTS, guess NO FLY LISTS aren't enough).  WHO KNOWS?!  My disk is working within specs after I racked my brain to solve the alignment problem ( I have 1.82 Tb of usable space after alignment and formatting ).  So buyer beware, caveat emptor, but it seems other hard disk manufacturers are switching to the higher 4096 Kb per sector formula, so make sure you can get the software UPFRONT at time of purchase, or else get ready for some major headaches before you can use the drive.  ZERO Stars for WD SUPPORT, 4 stars for the drive.

Reviews.Title: Good drive for DVR or Bluray player
Reviews.Author: slee02
Reviews.Content: I wanted to upgrade my 250gb hard drive in my LG BD-590 and BD-690 players, and I looked inside and they were using this type of model, but only 250gb.Everything seem fine and I formated it in the settings section of setting up the bluray players, and copied over some of my movies. The disadvantage was that LG stuck with 100mb and not 1000gb network ports, so it takes forever to transfer terabytes of movies....they run faster when they are local compared to streaming from my main box in the living room.

Reviews.Title: Doesn't perform as advertised in PVR
Reviews.Author: Gary Gendel
Reviews.Content: Replaced a failed drive in my Moxi PVR.  The drive doesn't seem to be able to keep up when streaming.  It freezes during playback, rewind, and fast forward for as much as 30 seconds.  On the good side, this is a very quiet drive compared to the original Seagate. Ordered a new Seagate to see if that works.  I'll relegate the WD as a backup drive.[Update] Got the Seagate ST2000DM001 and replaced the WD drive.  It is working flawlessly, does not freeze even at the highest fast-forward or rewind speeds. It seems to be as quiet as the WD drive as well.

Reviews.Title: Computer would not recognize drive- FIXED!
Reviews.Author: American Goth
Reviews.Content: Okay, I installed this drive in my computer, and it wouldn't show up in "My Computer". I found this website:[...]I followed the instructions, and it now works.These are the instructions:********************************************************************xpcman Oct 23, 2008 10:39PMYou need to format the drive before you can use it for data.Right-Click on the My Computer icon either on your desktop or in the Start Menu and select Manage.A new window titled Computer Management comes up.Select Storage from the left hand side by clicking it once, then select Disk Management(local) from the right side by double-clicking it. Find your new drive and format it with one large partition.First you partition - do a primary partition if you want only one partition on the hard drive. Then you format the partition - again right click and select format use NTSF - use default allocation size and give the new volume a label (no spaces allowed in the name).**************************************************************Of course, it took FOREVER to format. Maybe I should have used the Quick Format option....  ;)
